greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Least k >= 0 such that n*2^k - 1 or n*2^k + 1 is prime, or -1 if no such value exists.
comment: Fred Cohen and J. L. Selfridge showed that a(n) = -1 infinitely often.
a(n) = 0 iff n is in A045718.
A217892 and A194600 give indices and values of the records.
reference: Fred Cohen and J. L. Selfridge, Not every number is the sum or difference of two prime powers, Math. Comput. 29 (1975), 79-81.
link: Arkadiusz Wesolowski, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1000
Eric Weisstein's World of Mathematics, Brier Number
example: For n=7, 7*2^0-1 and 7*2^0+1 are composite, but 7*2^1-1=13 is prime, so a(7)=1.
mathematica: Table[k = 0; While[! PrimeQ[n*2^k - 1] && ! PrimeQ[n*2^k + 1], k++]; k, {n, 100}] (* _T. D. Noe_, Aug 29 2011 *)
results.author: _Arkadiusz Wesolowski_, Aug 29 2011
